channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Cameron halts press regulation talks
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron calls a halt to cross-party talks on press regulation, sparking anger from party leaders and victims of media intrusion.

item.title: Pope sounds warning to Catholics
item.description: Pope Francis warns that the Catholic Church will be just "a compassionate NGO" unless it focuses on its primary, religious mission.

item.title: MP Eric Joyce arrested at Parliament
item.description: Falkirk MP Eric Joyce is arrested after police are called to reports of a fight in a bar at the Houses of Parliament.

item.title: Early HIV drugs 'cure one in 10'
item.description: Rapid drug treatment after HIV infection may be enough to "functionally cure" about one in 10 patients, say researchers in France.

item.title: HMRC to close tax Enquiry Centres
item.description: The UK tax authority is to close all of its 281 Enquiry Centres which gave face-to-face help to 2.3 million people with tax queries last year.

item.title: Reuters man on Anonymous hack charge
item.description: Reuters journalist Matthew Keys is charged in the US with conspiring with hacking group Anonymous to break into the website of a former employer.

item.title: Detroit gets new financial manager
item.description: The US city of Detroit appoints an emergency manager to get a grip on the city's finances, in the biggest state takeover in 20 years.

item.title: Iran nuclear weapon 'over year away'
item.description: US President Barack Obama tells an Israeli TV channel that it would take Iran "over a year or so" to develop a nuclear weapon.

item.title: Death blaze dad 'did not bathe'
item.description: A man accused of starting a fire which killed six of his children says petrol was found on his clothes because he did not bathe or shower for 12 weeks.

item.title: Mirror journalists held over hacking
item.description: Four journalists or former journalists at Mirror Group Newspapers are arrested as police say for the first time they are probing alleged phone hacking at the firm.

item.title: Pork DNA found in halal school meat
item.description: Pork DNA is found in halal chicken sausages served in a central London primary school.

item.title: Eye-tracking Samsung Galaxy unveiled
item.description: Samsung has launched its latest flagship smartphone, the Galaxy S4, which allows users to control the device with their eyes.

item.title: Double lottery winner 'not bothered'
item.description: A man who won the lottery for the second time in less than two years has said he is "not that bothered" about his latest win.

item.title: Fed approves most bank capital plans
item.description: The US central bank says that most major US banks have strong enough balance sheets to proceed with their plans for payouts for shareholders.

item.title: EU summit: Austerity push challenged
item.description: Jobs and growth are expected to dominate an EU summit getting under way in Brussels.

item.title: Watchdog criticises TPim regime
item.description: Extreme restrictions on the movement of terror suspects are being imposed without sufficient proof of a threat, says the government's reviewer of terror legislation.

item.title: Expert plays down 'cyberwar' threat
item.description: Terror groups lack the technical expertise to launch a cyber-attack on Britain's national power and water systems, a security expert tells a committee of MPs.

item.title: UK 'not ready for ageing society'
item.description: The UK is "woefully underprepared" for the social and economic challenges presented by an ageing society, a Lords committee warns.

item.title: Conflicts 'rife' in new GP groups
item.description: More than a third of GPs on the boards of new NHS commissioning groups will have a potential conflict of interest, an investigation suggests.

item.title: Part-time student rate 'falls away'
item.description: There has been a "dramatic decline" in the number of people studying for degrees in England on a part-time basis, a report says.

item.title: Children 'needlessly criminalised'
item.description: Children in care are being drawn into the criminal justice system for "trivial incidents", MPs warn in a report.

item.title: Google to retire Reader service
item.description: Google is to shut down its web content aggregation service Reader in July, leaving some users very angry.

item.title: UK broadband hits double figures
item.description: The average broadband speed in the UK now stands at 12Mbps (megabits per second), according to Ofcom's latest report.

item.title: ‘Gang of eight’ on ivory probation
item.description: The Cites convention tells the worst ivory offenders to get their houses in order or face sanctions

item.title: UK firm joins ocean mineral rush
item.description: A new and controversial frontier in mining is opening up as a British firm joins a growing rush to exploit minerals in the depths of the oceans.

item.title: Parade's End scores four awards
item.description: World War I drama Parade's End receives four honours at this year's Broadcasting Press Guild Awards, including acting prizes for Benedict Cumberbatch and Rebecca Hall.

item.title: Film fraudsters convicted over scam
item.description: Five people have been convicted for a tax scam in which they tried to claim £2.8m for a Hollywood blockbuster which they never intended to make.

item.title: The strange status of 16-year-olds
item.description: Adulthood starts at 18, but those one or two years younger occupy are given many freedoms and responsibilities but denied others.

item.title: Why do Americans name mountains after presidents?
item.description: Why do some Americans want to name a mountain after Ronald Reagan?

item.title: Jockey McNamara injured in fall
item.description: Amateur jockey JT McNamara suffers a serious neck injury after a fall at the Cheltenham Festival.

item.title: Chelsea 3-1 Steaua Buch't (agg 3-2)
item.description: Fernando Torres scores the decisive goal as Chelsea beat Steaua Bucharest to reach the Europa League quarter-finals.

item.title: Inter Milan 4-1 Tottenham (agg 4-4)
item.description: Emmanuel Adebayor scores a crucial extra-time goal as Spurs lose 4-1 at Inter Milan but go through in the Europa League.

item.title: Fans want 'bloodbath' win - North
item.description: Wing George North says Wales fans want them to beat England in Cardiff amid a 'bloodbath' in the Six Nations on Saturday.

item.title: Anticipation in the Melbourne air
item.description: BBC Sport's Andrew Benson assesses the mood in the Melbourne paddock ahead of the opening race of the 2013 Formula 1 season

item.title: Campaigner wins 'extremism' case
item.description: A peace campaigner wins a legal battle to have his details removed from the police National Domestic Extremism Database.

item.title: Man jailed for lingerie boss murder
item.description: A man is jailed for life after being found guilty of beating to death the owner of an international lingerie firm.

item.title: Clegg says party makes a difference
item.description: The Scottish Liberal Democrat conference will hear UK leader Nick Clegg say his party is making a difference at Westminster and at Holyrood.

item.title: Scottish press regulation report due
item.description: An expert report on the regulation of the press in Scotland is to be published on Friday, it emerges.

item.title: Newspaper pays McAreavey damages
item.description: The libel action brought by John McAreavey against the Irish Daily Mail over pictures published of his murdered wife Michaela is settled.

item.title: Maze centre 'must reflect all views'
item.description: A senior republican ex-prisoner has said any new peace and reconciliation centre on the former Maze prison site must reflect the stories of all involved, including loyalists and the Army.

item.title: Health change in Welsh reshuffle
item.description: Mark Drakeford is named health minister in a surprise Welsh government reshuffle.

item.title: 43 new measles cases in outbreak
item.description: Health officials say 43 more cases of measles have been reported in the Swansea area in the last week, taking the outbreak to 252.

item.title: Botswana apologises over Kenyatta
item.description: Botswana apologises for saying that Kenya's President-elect Uhuru Kenyatta would be banned from the country if he refuses to co-operate with the ICC.

item.title: Malawi 'coup plotters' get bail
item.description: A Malawi court grants bail to 11 high-profile figures charged with treason over an alleged coup plot, including ex-President Bingu wa Mutharika's brother.

item.title: India orders Rome envoy not to leave
item.description: India's Supreme Court orders Italy's ambassador not to leave the country after Rome refuses to return two marines charged with murdering two fishermen.

item.title: Karzai talk 'put Nato lives at risk'
item.description: US and Nato troops in Afghanistan face greater risks after an "inflammatory speech" by President Hamid Karzai, Nato's top commander warns.

item.title: Spanish eviction rules 'unlawful'
item.description: The European Court of Justice rules that mortgage laws in Spain are too hard on borrowers who default.

item.title: France backs end to Syria arms ban
item.description: French President Francois Hollande backs calls for the EU arms embargo on Syria to be lifted to allow weapons to reach anti-government rebels.

item.title: Chavez 'unlikely to be embalmed'
item.description: The acting president of Venezuela, Nicolas Maduro says it is highly unlikely that the body of the former president Hugo Chavez will be embalmed.

item.title: UK halts new Brazil visa rules
item.description: Plans to impose visa restrictions on Brazilian tourists have been put on hold by Home Secretary Theresa May amid concerns about trade.

item.title: Israel PM 'reaches coalition deal'
item.description: The Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu reaches a deal to form a coalition government with the Yesh Atid and Jewish Home parties, officials say.

item.title: Bombers target Baghdad ministries
item.description: More than 20 people have been killed in a series of bomb and gun attacks on government buildings in the Iraqi capital Baghdad, police and medics say.

item.title: US panel approves assault guns ban
item.description: A sharply split US Senate panel passes a bill to ban assault weapons, but the measure is viewed as unlikely to go much further in Congress.

item.title: JP Morgan accused of hiding losses
item.description: US bank JPMorgan Chase is accused by a US Senate panel of hiding its huge "London whale" trading losses, worth $6.2bn (£4.1bn).

item.title: In pictures: F1 of yesterday
item.description: Get close to the stars and cars of the past

item.title: In pictures: Landmark: The Fields of Photography
item.description: Landscape photography show at Somerset House

item.title: In pictures: Pretending to live on Mars
item.description: The scientists who pretend to live on Mars

item.title: Day in pictures: 13 March 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 13 March

item.title: In pictures: Cardinals' conclave
item.description: Cardinals at the Vatican pray for divine guidance

item.title: In pictures: Let sleeping dogs lie
item.description: Photographer Alison Baskerville visits Crufts

item.title: In pictures: India's Kumbh Mela festival ends
item.description: India's 55-day-long festival closes

item.title: In pictures: Fidel and Che lots sold
item.description: Korda's photographs of Castro and Guevara

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: MP Sarah Wollaston launches fresh attack on the government's alcohol pricing policy.

item.title: VIDEO: The British businesses thriving in downturn
item.description: Although the UK economy is suffering its longest downturn for generations some British companies appear to be thriving.

item.title: VIDEO: Death blaze dad 'did not bathe'
item.description: A man accused of starting a fire which killed six of his children said petrol was found on his clothes because he did not have a bath or shower for 12 weeks.

item.title: VIDEO: Twisted toymaker on his 'wood cartoons'
item.description: Paul Spooner, a craftsman who makes 'animations in wood', gives a tour of his studio in Cornwall, and some of his recent works.

item.title: VIDEO: Party time for zoo's twin lemurs
item.description: A pair of ring-tailed lemurs at Whipsnade Zoo have reached the grand old age of 25.

item.title: VIDEO: The rise of UK's 'crumbling roads'
item.description: A third of drivers have suffered damage to their vehicles from potholes over the last two years, a survey suggests.

item.title: VIDEO: Jubilee film shows Queen's special year
item.description: A two hour fly-on-the-wall documentary following the Queen during her Diamond Jubilee year will be shown on ITV.

item.title: VIDEO: Deep sea mining plan for minerals
item.description: A British company has announced that it is planning to exploit a new and controversial frontier in the search for valuable minerals, by mining the sea bed in the Pacific Ocean.

item.title: AUDIO: 'I thought kidnappers would kill us'
item.description: The BBC's Mike Thomson speaks to a 15-year-old girl who was held by people traffickers in Eritrea.

item.title: How it became almost mandatory for dads to attend the birth
item.description: Is a father obliged to attend his baby's birth?

item.title: UK and Irish Catholics welcome Pope
item.description: Catholics in UK and Ireland give their take on new pontiff

item.title: Interactive video: Deep sea mining
item.description: How firms plan to extract precious metals from the seabed

item.title: In pictures: Royal Academicians
item.description: Royal Academicians, at work in their studios

item.title: What Japanese history lessons leave out
item.description: Why do Japanese children learn almost nothing about the war?

item.title: How a Tuscan wine said No to recession
item.description: How a top Italian wine defied the downturn

item.title: Viewpoints: What the economy needs
item.description: This is what we need to grow, say businesses and entrepreneurs

item.title: Farmers 'hanging on by fingertips'
item.description: The farmers struggling to keep their livestock fed

item.title: How pretty is the UK without the "bad bits"?
item.description: What does UK economy look like without the “bad bits”?

item.title: Why old age need not be a burden
item.description: Why old age does not have to equal a burden
